title: What is happening with me?
content: I am 39 year old male who has smoked 2 packs per day for 20 years. I have been very healthy until the last 12 months. During this time I have had a kidney infection. After that cleared up I began having stomach problems and after an endoscopy was diagnosed with an ulcer and hiatal hernia. author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, Small lymph nodes (<1cm) are usually reactive. If the clinical examination suggests that a lymph node enlargement is a benign condition then follow up for 2 weeks to 1 month is warranted. During this period any change in size or new symptoms should be reported immediately. The next step would be a CT scan of the head and neck. A biopsy of the node is only done as a very last resort as it has serious drawbacks on therapy if it does turn out to be a cancer.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Wed May 18, 2005 2:25 am

posted_time: Post  by Steven » Mon Apr 18, 2005 2:12 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello Steven, An elevated white cell count could mean almost anything from a benign transient reaction to an infection or the more alarming conditions which you have read about (leukemias). Your doctor is correct to order a differential count as this will usually differentiate between the range of conditions mentioned above. 13,000 is not alarmingly high though. So I would not worry too much until the results of the differential come out. Leukemias as well as many other myeloproliferative disorders the total leukocytic counts are above 20,000 (commonly above 30,000) at the time of diagnosis. Let me know how everything turns out.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Mon Apr 18, 2005 2:31 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi eveline1, There are numerous reasons for blood clots. When the blood flow is slowed for example, by inactivity, blood tends to "pool", become sluggish, collect in the area of inactivity (especially the legs). Blood clots are usually treated with administration of a blood thinner, which disolves the clots. In my opinion the blood clot would be due to the inactivity. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: judywbates, You can find info about this rare disease on this very site by clicking on the following link: Pheochromocytoma. You may find more information elsewhere on the internet. I would advise an isotopic scan as part of her workup to exclude extramedullary disease. If it turns out that there is no evidence of metastasis and no symptoms then she should be put under follow up.

title: My doctor ordered a transvaginal ultrasound, why?
content: I recently went to the gyno and she asked me to see a radiologist in the next few weeks for a transvaginal sonogram. Is this normal? Should I be worried? I'm only 24 and in great shape/health except for a benign pituitary tumor which has been under control for over a year now. Can anyone help?
posted_time: Post  by MNB1202 » Tue Mar 15, 2005 10:42 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi MNB1202, Transvaginal Ultrasounds or sonograms enable the radiologist to have a closer look at the pelvic structures (uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and cervix). It may identify uterine fibroids, ovarian cysts, fertility concerns, etc. etc. It would be difficult to say why in particular your physician ordered this test without knowing if there were any concerns voiced at your appointment. If nothing abnormal was indicated during your appointment it may be to evaluate for fertility concerns. You may want to give the physician a telephone call and ask why in particular this test was ordered for an explaination. Sincerely, Rntdj

posted_time: Post  by imreneelaura » Tue Jan 04, 2005 1:15 pm

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Thyroid
content: My apologies for the delay in your getting a response to your question.  There has been a backlog of questions here at The lounge.  We are endeavoring to respond to all questions, including old ones.  As more of us are responding to questions, we hope to be able to respond to new questions in a timely manner.  I hope that you will visit The Lounge again and that you next experience here will be better than your last.  It is not uncommon that needle aspirations of thyroid findings return back "non-diagnostic" or "insufficient".  In such cases, it would be reasonable to see an Endocrinologist whom could evaluate the thyroid further.  I don't tend to just monitor the situation in such a case.  I get an Endocrinologist's opinion and expertise to help me.  Sometimes a formal biopsy is needed to get enough tissue material to run the required tests to see if there is a cancer present.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

content: Hi, I'm hoping someone cangive me some common sense advice.   Over 15 months ago I noticed that the joint where my 3rd anterior rib is joined to the sternum had grown larger.  It did not particularly hurt unless I pressed on it firmly or frequently, in which case it felt a bit sore.  When  my Dr.first felt it she thought perhaps I had slipped a rib.   But I had not.   I hadr a chest PA last January and it showed nothing.   Then in April  I had a set of x-rays done.  One frontal and two angled to better show the ribs.  I have some very decent films of my posterior ribs, but the ant. are not well shown. There was no lesion shown in these either.    My Dr. did not seem concerned about the lump and said that people often get nobblylas they age and that is is not so uncommon.  I was not happy to hear this at 37 years old, but felt that I was being overly anxious about it all and and decided to  let it drop.   Recently, I noticed that the lump has grown.  Itt was beginning to be painful if one of my kids lay their head on my chest, and occasionally it was beginning to ache.  I brought it up again a couple of months ago and she mentioned we could do a FNA of the cartilage at some point.  Then I brought it up again 2 weeks ago when I last saw my her and againshe said we could look into doing FNA of the cartilage and MRI.  However, neither was scheduled.  This  leads me to believe that she is not too concerned, which I hope is good news.  However, she has not felt the lump at  any time in the last year, and it is definitely growing.  I have thoroughly palpitated the entire are from each arm pit to about the 7 or 8th rib.  The entire 3rd rib is now thicker and the fourth has a place that is getting thicker.  The joint where the lump is , is visable larger than the others on my chest.   I decided I really want to get this done and called her office to get the process going last week.  Nothing happened,  so I called again on Monday and actually spoke with her.   She said that the hold up for scheduling the MRI has been that she's not sure what if it is the right type of imaging that would be best for this.  After speaking with me and realizing that the whole bone is involved, she will not be doing the FNA.  She said that she would speak with the radiologist about what kind of imaging to do, but I have not heard back from her yet.   I have had 7 dysplastic nevi removed and also a  recent thyroid ultrasound  discovered two  nodules.   I am concerned about possibly having cancer with a bone  metastisis.  Am I worrying for nothing?  Or should I be pushing to get the imaging done quickly?    I feel that I have been patient for over a year, but I really want to know what the heck is growing in me. author: Delia  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Thu Dec 30, 2004 1:01 pm Location: Texas
title: Lymphoid Nodule in Bone Marrow Biopsy
content: Hello,  I need some clarification on my recent bone marrow biopsy for pancytopenia.  The report states that there was a single non-paratrabecular lymphoid nodule of uncertain clinical significance found in the bone marrow core biopsy.  It goes on to stat under comments "to clarify the significance of the small lympoid nodule present in the bone marrow core biopsy immunohistochemistry studies were attempted.  However, the lymphoid nodule was not present in the sections cut at (name of lab).  This doesn't make any sense to me since all lab materials were sent to the same place.  Should I be concerned by the lymphoid nodule?  My hematologist placed me on iron capsules as the bone marrow also indicated absent iron stores despite normal blood iron and total iron binding capacity values.    Thank you very much Delia
posted_time: Post  by Delia » Sun Jan 02, 2005 10:33 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Dear Delia, I have already answered this question in a different thread. Please keep all the posts in one thread as this makes it easier for the doctors to follow up on your question.  To explain a bit more, a lymphoid nodule occurs when there is a reaction to some immune process. Lymph cells start to aggregate and form nodules to participate in the immune reaction. This can be seen in the marrow exam as a nodule. Nodules can also form in the marrow in lymphoproliferative disorders and hematological malignancies of lymphoid origin. To differentiate the two types immunohistochemistry is performed to determine whether the cells in the nodule are monoclonal or polyclonal. Monoclonal means they all come from the same mother cell, this is common with malignancy where many cells are produced from one 'malignant' clone. Polyclonality means this is a normal immune reaction coming from many differnt clones of healthy lymph cells that have multiplied to participate in the immune reaction.   Immune reactions of this nature are nonmalignant but can be the result of several diseases: infections, allergic reactions, autoimmune diseases.   The reason why we think its probably not malignant is because malignancies of lymph system would clearly show up on routine blood count and bone marrow examination. They would not show up as pancytopenia without the presence of a very large number of malignant cells that have taken up all the healthy space in the marrow and rendered it unusable by normal cells.   If you are still concerned you may add the results of the various marrow elements expressed with their relative normal limits.   Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, Its hard to tell over the internet. However if it is in the actual earlobe as you say, then what you feel is likely a type of cyst called an Epidermal Inclusion Cyst or EIC. These lesions are not unlike a pimple. These cysts contain dead skin cells, sebum, and purulent fluid encapsulated in a fibrous shell. They sometimes become inflamed for no apparent reason. If you were to squeeze the cyst (which I’m sure you have done in the past), you might notice a bit of white thready discharge. However, these types of lesions won't pop like a pimple, because the fluid is contained inside of a protective shell. This is the body's way of isolating foreign material and protecting surrounding tissues. You should not try to pop or squeeze EIC's. You can actually cause damage to the surrounding tissue. These lesions must be removed surgically. It's really a pretty simple procedure, and is typically done in the doctor's office.  Ofcourse there are several other possibilities. Either way you should have it checked out.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Mon Jul 26, 2004 11:58 pm

title: [no title]
content: Dear jarik, As bill said it could be a  benign swelling,  however careful history and examination are extremely important in your case to exclude any other possibilities and to determine the need for further investigations. More details about the swelling could help, is it associated with any signs of trauma (bruises, ecchymosed path, a trauma can pass unnoticed). Is there any sign of inflammation (redness, oedema, usually painful ). Is it increasing in size, decreasing , stable? Did you lose weight the last few month may be u just noticed an old swelling because you have lost some weight. Is it mobile can u make it move a little bit (bone masses are fixed, skin or subcutaneous masses move). Hope to hear from you soon.

author: ATL  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jul 10, 2003 9:15 am
title: Cancer and Fertility Drugs
content: I have heard conflicting reports about the long term effects of the use of fertility drugs such as Lupron, Follistim, Repronex, Clomid, etc.  I have heard that they may or may not increase my chances of getting ovarian, breast, cervical, uterine and endometrial cancers as well as increasing the likelihood of speeding the growth of other non reproductive types of cancers.  I would like to hear the expert opinion of an oncologist on the issue as my husband and I decide our path to resolve our infertility issues.  Thank you
posted_time: Post  by ATL » Thu Jul 10, 2003 9:56 am

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Infertility treatments and cancer
content: ATL,  I am not an infertility specialist.  From what I am aware, most fertility treatments stimulate ovarian function.  There has been a concern about various medical treatments that either use estrogens (for example, hormone replacement therapy when a woman is post-menopausal) or stimulate the ovaries could increase the risk of a cancer from the organ being stimulated (e.g.- the ovaries)  or increase the irsk of cancer sensitive to the hormone (e.g.- breast cancer).  There has been controversy because the data does conflict, mainly due to clinical studies looking at the issue from different perspectives or from different ways.  Some studies were poorly designed.  Others had flaws that limited the results being interpreted.  There may be a risk of ovarian cancer from the use of infertility drugs.  There are other non-cancer medical risks.  I would recommend that you discuss the benefits and risks of various treatment options available to you not only between your husband and you, but between your doctor.  An honest discussions about these issues will hopefully let you make an informed decision.  No decision that has uncertainty about it is an easy one.  I wish you the best.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Jeffrey Gordon » Sat Jul 26, 2003 7:44 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: Oral Cancer
content: pureeuphoria, It is incredibly difficult to evaluate and reply to questions like yours over the internet. Hence since I cannot properly evaluate the condition I would be obliged to refer you for a proper physical exam.  To answer your questions. Yes lumps in the mouth could be a cancer (they could be a dozen harmless things as well). Yes tobacco is associated with increased incidence of oral cancer (although you aren't a heavy smoker).  Best thing is to address the issue directly, get yourself examined by a physician and end your worries. Best regards,
